{"abstract": "The World Economic Forum will take place in Davos, Switzerland; the European Commission will publish its proposals on climate change policy; and Microsoft will release its earnings.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/20/business/economy/economic-reports-for-the-week-of-jan-20.html", "snippet": "The World Economic Forum will take place in Davos, Switzerland; the European Commission will publish its proposals on climate change policy; and Microsoft will release its earnings.", "lead_paragraph": "GATHERING IN DAVOS The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, will begin with a ceremony on Tuesday evening. World leaders scheduled to attend the forum include Shinzo Abe, prime minister of Japan; David Cameron, prime minister of Britain; Benjamin Netanyahu, prime minister of Israel; and Hassan Rouhani, president of Iran. The United States will be represented by Jacob J. Lew, the Treasury secretary; Penny Pritzker, secretary of commerce; and Gina McCarthy, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, who will discuss President Obama\u2019s climate action plan. This year\u2019s celebrity in residence is Matt Damon, who will receive an award for his charitable work. Some of the speeches and panels will be posted on the forum\u2019s website, weforum.org.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Economic Reports for the Week of Jan. 20", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Looking Ahead", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "glocations", "value": "Davos (Switzerland)", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "LightSquared", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "European Commission", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Microsoft Corporation", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-01-19T22:25:52+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Economy", "byline": {"original": "", "person": [], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "List", "_id": "nyt://article/d85d353a-b9f9-52db-bb5a-2e5ce8c574d8", "word_count": 308, "uri": "nyt://article/d85d353a-b9f9-52db-bb5a-2e5ce8c574d8"}

{"abstract": "Standard & Poor\u2019s lowers Puerto Rico\u2019s debt to junk status. | Morgan Stanley reaches a $1.25 billion mortgage settlement with the F.H.F.A. | Microsoft names a new chief executive. | The Deal Professor discusses Herbalife\u2019s volatile stock price.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/02/05/morning-agenda-a-debt-downgrade-for-puerto-rico/", "snippet": "Standard & Poor\u2019s lowers Puerto Rico\u2019s debt to junk status. | Morgan Stanley reaches a $1.25 billion mortgage settlement with the F.H.F.A. | Microsoft names a new chief executive. | The Deal Professor discusses Herbalife\u2019s volatile stock price.", "lead_paragraph": "Standard & Poor\u2019s lowered the debt of Puerto Rico to junk status on Tuesday, sending shock waves through the investor community, which has long enjoyed the tax-exempt interest generated by the island\u2019s municipal bonds. {"abstract": "Joe Belfiore, the corporate vice president of Microsoft Windows Phone, discusses goals for 2014 and the potential upside of the company\u2019s Nokia deal.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/02/23/q-a-with-joe-belfiore-on-the-future-of-windows-phone/", "snippet": "Joe Belfiore, the corporate vice president of Microsoft Windows Phone, discusses goals for 2014 and the potential upside of the company\u2019s Nokia deal.", "lead_paragraph": "Joe Belfiore is the corporate vice president of Microsoft Windows Phone, and he oversees the software that powers handsets using the company\u2019s operating system. Microsoft is expected to close its $7.2 billion deal to buy the handset and services division of Nokia by the end of March. The acquisition will give Microsoft control of both mobile software and hardware, as it looks to expand its 4 percent market share in global smartphone sales. Mr. Belfiore will play a crucial role in Microsoft\u2019s efforts to take on Apple and the cellphone makers that use Google\u2019s Android operating system. ", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/02/23/business/23bits-belfiore/23bits-belfiore-articleLarge.jpg", "height": 400, "width": 600, "subType": "xlarge", "crop_name": "articleLarge", "legacy": {"xlarge": "images/2014/02/23/business/23bits-belfiore/23bits-belfiore-articleLarge.jpg", "xlargewidth": 600, "xlargeheight": 400}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/02/23/business/23bits-belfiore/23bits-belfiore-jumbo.jpg", "height": 682, "width": 1024, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "superJumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/02/23/business/23bits-belfiore/23bits-belfiore-superJumbo.jpg", "height": 1365, "width": 2048, "subType": "superJumbo", "crop_name": "superJumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbnail", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/02/23/business/23bits-belfiore/23bits-belfiore-thumbStandard-v2.jpg", "height": 75, "width": 75, "subType": "thumbnail", "crop_name": "thumbStandard", "legacy": {"thumbnail": "images/2014/02/23/business/23bits-belfiore/23bits-belfiore-thumbStandard-v2.jpg", "thumbnailwidth": 75, "thumbnailheight": 75}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbLarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2014/02/23/business/23bits-belfiore/23bits-belfiore-thumbLarge-v2.jpg", "height": 150, "width": 150, "subType": "thumbLarge", "crop_name": "thumbLarge", "legacy": {}}], "headline": {"main": "Q.&A. {"abstract": "Dollar General takes its bid for Family Dollar directly to shareholders. | Microsoft near a deal for the maker of Minecraft. | Fed\u2019s newly proposed rules put pressure on banks. | Detroit clears a bankruptcy hurdle.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/09/10/morning-agenda-dollar-general-goes-hostile/", "snippet": "Dollar General takes its bid for Family Dollar directly to shareholders. | Microsoft near a deal for the maker of Minecraft. | Fed\u2019s newly proposed rules put pressure on banks. | Detroit clears a bankruptcy hurdle.", "lead_paragraph": "Dollar General said on Wednesday that it was taking its $9.1 billion offer for Family Dollar directly to shareholders, DealBook\u2019s David Gelles writes. The move could further complicate Family Dollar\u2019s deal agreement to sell itself to Dollar Tree for $8.5 billion. In a statement, Dollar General said it was offering to acquire all of Family Dollar\u2019s shares for $80 each. That is the same bid that Family Dollar rejected last week, contending that the deal it agreed to with Dollar Tree had a better chance of passing muster with antitrust regulators. A hostile bid is likely to, at the very least, delay any deal between Family Dollar and Dollar Tree.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Dollar General Goes Hostile", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-09-10T11:44:42+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/9b7a4712-e0bb-52b7-81e4-ea12781543ba", "word_count": 1744, "uri": "nyt://article/9b7a4712-e0bb-52b7-81e4-ea12781543ba"}

{"abstract": "Microsoft\u2019s acquisition of Minecraft would be an acknowledgment that games are central to many people\u2019s lives, as players can spend months building estates and entire countries.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/09/11/daily-report-in-popular-games-tech-titans-see-potential-beyond-fun/", "snippet": "Microsoft\u2019s acquisition of Minecraft would be an acknowledgment that games are central to many people\u2019s lives, as players can spend months building estates and entire countries.", "lead_paragraph": "Parents like Minecraft because it can be a creative outlet for their children, Nick Wingfield reports. Teachers like the game because it can bring lessons to life. {"abstract": "Even as many barriers have fallen for working women, they continue to be treated differently on the job, particularly when negotiating a raise.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/11/upshot/satya-nadellas-advice-on-raises-stirs-wider-discussion-among-women.html", "snippet": "Even as many barriers have fallen for working women, they continue to be treated differently on the job, particularly when negotiating a raise.", "lead_paragraph": "When Satya Nadella, Microsoft\u2019s chief executive, told a conference of women in tech on Thursday that they should not ask for a raise, but trust \u201cfaith\u201d and \u201ckarma\u201d to reward them appropriately, he not only caused an immediate stir at his own company and other tech companies, but {"abstract": "Uber closes a $1.2 billion round of financing. | The owners of the 76ers are taking a page out of the private equity playbook. | Only 11 bidders took part in the second Bitcoin auction. | Microsoft and Barnes & Noble end their Nook partnership.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/12/05/morning-agenda-uber-garners-40-billion-valuation/", "snippet": "Uber closes a $1.2 billion round of financing. | The owners of the 76ers are taking a page out of the private equity playbook. | Only 11 bidders took part in the second Bitcoin auction. | Microsoft and Barnes & Noble end their Nook partnership.", "lead_paragraph": "UBER GARNERS $40 BILLION VALUATION | Uber is amassing a war chest to be the world\u2019s private driving service, Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. On Thursday, the start-up closed a new $1.2 billion round of financing, with investors valuing the company at a staggering $40 billion. This comes on top of the $1.5 billion that Uber had already raised. And Uber may not be done yet. The company may eventually sell an additional $600 million in stock, and it is working with Goldman Sachs to sell, potentially, another $1 billion in debt to some of the Wall Street firm\u2019s wealthy private clients.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Uber Garners $40 Billion Valuation", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-12-05T13:10:57+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a1178cc1-4aba-5399-bfd6-0c2d5c8c7a87", "word_count": 2537, "uri": "nyt://article/a1178cc1-4aba-5399-bfd6-0c2d5c8c7a87"}

{"abstract": "With the latest earnings reports from Microsoft and Apple, the once-unthinkable became reality: Apple\u2019s market capitalization hit $683 billion, more than double Microsoft\u2019s $338 billion.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/30/business/how-and-why-apple-overtook-microsoft.html", "snippet": "With the latest earnings reports from Microsoft and Apple, the once-unthinkable became reality: Apple\u2019s market capitalization hit $683 billion, more than double Microsoft\u2019s $338 billion.", "lead_paragraph": "When Microsoft stock was at a record high in 1999, and its market capitalization was nearly $620 billion, the notion that Apple Computer would ever be bigger \u2014 let alone twice as big \u2014 was laughable. {"abstract": "Car title loans are drawing scrutiny from regulators. | Law firm founds a project to fight \u201crevenge porn.\u201d | Shake Shack is going public with big dreams. | How Apple beat Microsoft.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2015/01/30/morning-agenda-crackdown-on-car-title-loans/", "snippet": "Car title loans are drawing scrutiny from regulators. | Law firm founds a project to fight \u201crevenge porn.\u201d | Shake Shack is going public with big dreams. | How Apple beat Microsoft.", "lead_paragraph": "CRACKDOWN ON LOANS LINKED TO CARS | Car title loans, which allow owners to borrow money against their cars, are under fire, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery report in DealBook. On Friday, the Federal Trade Commission is expected to announce that it has reached a settlement with two car title lenders, First American Title Lending and Finance Select, over suspicions that they misled borrowers by failing to accurately disclose the terms and costs of the loans, according to people briefed on the action. The agreement will require the companies, both based in Georgia, to overhaul how they advertise and promote their loans, the people said.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Crackdown on Car Title Loans", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2015-01-30T12:42:46+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/5257ba8e-6122-5704-8cd2-f8b27bf09f31", "word_count": 2295, "uri": "nyt://article/5257ba8e-6122-5704-8cd2-f8b27bf09f31"}

{"abstract": "The trouble is that with fresh cash in hand or the slate wiped clean from an old deal, there is almost always a wide-eyed desire for a new one.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/12/business/dealbook/tech-breakups-show-bigger-is-not-necessarily-better.html", "snippet": "The trouble is that with fresh cash in hand or the slate wiped clean from an old deal, there is almost always a wide-eyed desire for a new one.", "lead_paragraph": "Symantec is revealing the truth about tech mergers and acquisitions. Offloading its data storage and recovery business Veritas for $8 billion to the buyout firm Carlyle and GIC of Singapore ends a decade-long disaster of a deal. Like Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and others, Symantec discovered that it can be harder to buy than to build. The resulting carve-ups and write-downs, though, have a tendency to perpetuate the problem.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": {"abstract": "Apple, Microsoft and Amazon will announce their quarterly reports, the Fed will gather for the first time this year, and American and European negotiators have until Sunday to reach an agreement.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/25/business/tech-giants-earnings-the-fed-meets-and-a-deadline-on-a-data-sharing-deal.html", "snippet": "Apple, Microsoft and Amazon will announce their quarterly reports, the Fed will gather for the first time this year, and American and European negotiators have until Sunday to reach an agreement.", "lead_paragraph": "This week\u2019s quarterly earnings announcements will include results from three of the technology sector\u2019s most important companies: Apple, Microsoft and Amazon. Investors on Tuesday will try to divine from Apple\u2019s numbers just how quickly the company\u2019s growth is decelerating. Their focus will be on iPhone sales. On Thursday, Microsoft and Amazon investors will want to see strong growth in both companies\u2019 computing services businesses. Although Microsoft is an important software maker and Amazon is one the world\u2019s most successful e-commerce businesses, those companies also run two of the largest cloud services companies, selling remote computing services and information storage. \u2014Katie Benner", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", {"abstract": "In order to be of use, assistants like Cortana and Siri need to know a lot about you. Reading the companies\u2019 privacy statements can give you an idea of how much.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/28/technology/personaltech/protecting-personal-information-from-virtual-assistants.html", "snippet": "In order to be of use, assistants like Cortana and Siri need to know a lot about you. Reading the companies\u2019 privacy statements can give you an idea of how much.", "lead_paragraph": "Q. I was going to try Cortana, Microsoft\u2019s version of Siri, but to use it, you have to allow Microsoft access to your location, your contacts, voice input, information from email and text messages, browser history, search history, calendar details \u201cand other information.\u201d Naturally, I declined.
